lines.content: Need advice? Making a list? Steven's the bot!
- Creating lists of actions to make
- Saving said actions to be read again later
- Marking, deleting and so forth of tasks
- [x] `help` whenever you're not sure what to do
# Sounds great! How do I download it?
3. Let it run! **Its as simple as that!**
> Steven's advice: Don't wait! Install now!
~~Please understand that Steven is not indeed sentient~~

Steven is a bot that helps you keep track of things like your deadlines, events, deadlines and so forth! With a simple command, you too can easily keep track of the little things in your schedule!
Adds a "deadline" item to the task list. A deadline is defined as a task with an end date
- `date1` must strictly be a date in the fromat `yyyy-mm-dd`
Adds a "todo" item to the task list. A todo is defined as a task with no start or end date
Adds a "event" item to the task list. A event is defined as a task with a start and end date
- `date1` and `date2` must strictly be a date in the fromat `yyyy-mm-dd`
## Listing what the current task list is: `list`
Displays the current list, even if there is nothing in the list, in which case nothing will be displayed as the list.
Marks an item in the list. While the definition of a "mark" is relatively arbitrary, it can be thought of as just noting something as done or not done.
- `x` is the index of the item as noted by its position in the list (to view this list, one can use `list`)
Example: `mark 1` - this marks the first item in the list.
Unarks an item in the list. While the definition of a "mark" is relatively arbitrary, it can be thought of as just noting something as done or not done.
- `x` is the index of the item as noted by its position in the list (to view this list, one can use `list`)
Example: `unmark 1` - this unmarks the first item in the list.
Deletes an item in the list. Note that deleting an item may cause the indices of items in the list to be changed.
- `x` is the index of the item as noted by its position in the list (to view this list, one can use `list`)

Finds an item with the specified name in the list, then shows a list of tasks which match the specified item name. Note that so long as an item contains the words listed, it will be searched out with this command.
- `name` is the name of the item that you want to search.

- this will return any task which contains "the" in part of its name. Consequently, with the above command, the following items will be shown. Note the presence of the set of letters that form "the" in the following examples.

- However, the search does not return tasks which have the specified word, but is broken up in some way. Again using the same example command, the following will **not** be searched out with this command.
Sorts the task list. The order can be specified by the user. Note that this affects the ordering of the list, so be sure to use `list` if you need to check the new indices of the items in the list.
- `asc` is used to sort the list in lexicographical order, ascending, so an event `AA` will be before `AC`, and `AC` will be before `ZZ`.
- `des` is used to sort the list in lexicographical order, descending, so an event `AA` will be after `AC`, and `AC` will be after `ZZ`.
- note that this spelling of "asc" or "dec" must strictly be followed.
Shows the user a list of commands that can be used.
- note that there is a small delay between the program closing and typing in of the command
- commands can be typed in this time, but it may cause corruption of data. Type at your own risk.
Data is saved in the hard disk, so manual backup is not necessary.
Data is saved in the file data/Steven.txt. Note that editing this file might result in corrupted data and/or unintended behavior. Edit at your own risk!
* an action which adds a Deadline item to the list
* executes the given task, modifying the tasklist accordingly
* @return the string containing the Steven's response to the task.
public String execute(UserInput userInput, TaskList taskList) {
outputString += "I see. I shall add the following to the list of tasks:\n";
outputString += String.format("Do bear in mind that you now have %d tasks in the list.%n", taskList.size());
outputString += String.format(FORMAT_ERROR + "Steven's advice: The format of \"Deadline\" is as follows:"
+ "\nDeadline (item) /by (date) - item is the name of an item that you want to add to the "
+ "list as a deadline. date must be a date.");
* an action which removes the index of a particular item from the list
* executes the given task, modifying the tasklist accordingly
* @return the string containing the Steven's response to the task.
public String execute(UserInput userInput, TaskList taskList) {
outputString += String.format("Very well, the following item has been removed from the"
outputString += "For the sake of completeness, this is the current list, do take note if any of "
+ "your items have been moved around in order.\n";
outputString += String.format(FORMAT_ERROR + "Steven's advice: The format of \"Delete\" is as follows:\n"
+ "delete (x) - x is an number corresponding with the index of an item in the list.");
outputString += "Oh, I can't  delete that - I need a number of an item in the list to delete it."
outputString += "Apologies, you don't have a task of this number, so I can't delete it."
+ "\nSteven's advice: Use a number which corresponds to a task number. If you need to know"
+ "what number corresponds to what task, use \"list\".";
* an action which adds an Event item to the list
* executes the given task, modifying the tasklist accordingly
* @return the string containing the Steven's response to the task.
public String execute(UserInput userInput, TaskList taskList) {
outputString += "I see. I shall add the following to the list of tasks:\n";
System.out.printf("Do bear in mind that you now have %d tasks in the list.%n", taskList.size());
+ "(item) /from (date1) /to (date2) - item is the name of an item that you want to add to the "
+ "list as a deadline. date1 and date2 must be dates.");
outputString += "Now hold on, this doesn't make sense! How can you have an event start earlier "
+ "than it ends?\nSteven's advice: Make sure your first date is before the second!";
* an action which finds tasks with matching names in the list

outputString += String.format("Ah, so you're looking for tasks with the word %s? Sure! "

protected static final String CORRUPTED = "Oh dear, looks like the file used to handle the data "
+ "\nSteven's Advice: You may need to re-create the file!";
protected static final String FORMAT_ERROR = "My, it would appear as though you didn't"
protected static final String DATE_ERR = "Ah, this one might be slightly complicated - "
+ "I need your date in the format of \"yyyy-mm-dd\", "
+ "and I'm quite strict with this, unfortunately."
+ "\nSteven's advice: Follow the format, append your days/months with zero as necessary! "
+ "For example, \"03\" is accepted for the month of March, but not \"3\"!";
* executes the given task, modifying the tasklist accordingly
* @return the string containing the Steven's response to the task.
public abstract String execute(UserInput userInput, TaskList taskList);
* an action which displays the list of commands for Steven

private static final String HELP4 = "mark (x) - marks the xth item on the list as complete. Note that an "
private static final String HELP5 = "unmark (x) - marks the xth item on the list as incomplete. Note than an"
private static final String HELP6 = "todo (item) - adds a todo item to the list.\n";
private static final String HELP7 = "deadline (item) /by (date1) - adds a deadline item to the list"
+ "date1. The format for both dates must be \"yyyy-mm-dddd\".\n";
private static final String HELP8 = "event (item) /from (date1) /to (date2) - adds an event item "
+ "on date1 and ends on date2. The format for both dates must be \"yyyy-mm-dddd\".\n";
private static final String HELP9 = "delete (x) - delete the xth item from the list. Do note "
private static final String HELP10 = "find (item) - finds any items in the list and prints them out, giving "
private static final String HELP11 = "sort (asc/des) - sorts the user's task list in ascending or descending order"
+ " respectively, where \"asc\" or \"des\" is given as the second parameter.";

return String.format(HELP1 + HELP2 + HELP3 + HELP4 + HELP5 + HELP6 + HELP7 + HELP8 + HELP9 + HELP10 + HELP11);
* To mark a task as complete

public String execute(UserInput userInput, TaskList taskList) {
outputString += "As you wish, this task will be marked:\n";
outputString += String.format(FORMAT_ERROR + "Steven's advice: The format of \"mark\" is as follows:"
+ "\nunmark (x) - x is an number corresponding with the index of an item in the list.");
outputString += "Hmm... Seems like you want me to mark something, but you didn't provide a "
+ "valid number for me to work off.\nSteven's Advice: Use a number instead.";
outputString += "Ah, a pity... Seems like you don't have that many tasks.\nSteven's advice: "
+ "Use a number which corresponds to a task number. If you need to know what number "
outputString += "Wait a moment, this one's already complete! I can't mark it as such again!."
+ "\nSteven's advice: You might have wanted to use\"unmark\" instead!";

+ " \"des\" if you want to sort the list in a descending order instead!";

* Class for receiving user input and storing it as separate arguments.
* It will separate the user's input into a name and 3 arguments.
* The name will be the first word, separated by whitespace
* the other 3 parameters will be separated by the terms "/from", "/by", and "/to".
* If any of the 3 parameters are left blank, then it will be treated as null.
* @param input String input of the user
